ğŸ” Top-to-Bottom Flow
Does your resume naturally guide the readerâ€™s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? Thatâ€™s the most critical partâ€”if itâ€™s hard to find, youâ€™re doing yourself a disservice.

ğŸ“‚ Key Details at a Glance
Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.

ğŸ¯ Communicating Accomplishments
Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments youâ€™d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.

If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. It's one of the most common questions hiring managers have when reviewing a resume. "What's that company do?"

Tip of the Week: Your Resume Should Be a Movie Trailer, Not the Whole Script

If your resume reads like a generic job description, we have a problem. Hiring managers donâ€™t want to see a list of what you were supposed to doâ€”they want to see what you actually did.

Saying â€œManaged cloud infrastructureâ€ is the resume equivalent of saying you â€œexistedâ€ at work. Instead, try â€œOptimized cloud resources to cut hosting costs by 35% while improving system uptime to 99.98%.â€

See the difference? Numbers, results, and real impact make you stand out.

Think of your resume like a movie trailerâ€”it should hook the audience, highlight the best moments, and leave them wanting more. What projects did you crush? What problems did you solve? How did your work make life easier, faster, or more efficient for your team? If your resume doesnâ€™t make hiring managers excited to learn more, itâ€™s time for a rewrite.

Hiring managers want problem-solvers, not a recap of job duties. Show them the action, the impact, and the results.

Whatâ€™s the best resume tip that helped you land an interview? Drop it in the comments!

â€œProductive Perspectiveâ€ #11

âŒCommon Resume Mistakes That Can Get You Rejected Instantly!

As a hashtag#recruiter reviewing countless resumes daily, I still see candidates making these avoidable mistakes. Here are some key reasons why resumes get rejected at first glance:

1. Grammatical & Spelling Errors â€“ A resume full of typos reflects a lack of attention to detail. Proofread carefully or use tools like Grammarly.

2. Listing Every Possible Tool & Technology â€“ Donâ€™t just add all buzzwords to get a call. Only mention technologies you have actual hands-on experience with.

3. Over-Reliance on AI-Generated Resumes â€“ Using AI (like ChatGPT) to refine your resume is fine, but copying generic content can make it sound impersonal and irrelevant to your real experience.

4. Frequent Job Hopping Without Explanation â€“ If your resume shows job changes every few months or years, it raises red flags for recruiters. Address it in your profile summary if needed.

5. Vague One-Word Responsibilities â€“ Writing generic words like â€œImplementation,â€ â€œDevelopment,â€ or â€œSupportâ€ for every project doesnâ€™t help. Be specific about your contributions.

6. Missing Project Durations & Education Year â€“ Always mention the timeline for each project and your education year to avoid confusion about experience level.

Want to stand out? Avoid these mistakes and craft a resume that truly reflects your skills and experience!

post_html:
With over 250 applications per job opening on average, that resume needs a strategic approach to consistently grab the attention needed to get you in the door.

So, is yours designed for easy consumption and comprehension? If you are only paying attention to what goes in it and not how it is delivered, you might have a problem.

Hiring managers and recruiters spend hours reviewing resumes, their eyes weary and strained. Respect their time by ensuring your resume is easy to read and navigate.

Here are some best practices for making your resume as readable as possible:

ğŸ“œ Use a Clean Design: Stick to professional fonts (like Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman) and avoid unnecessary graphics or images. Keep font sizes between 10 and 12 points for readability.

ğŸ“œ Structure for Navigation: Use clear headings, bold job titles, and bullet points to guide the reader through your experience. Think of your resume as if it were a map. Navigation cues will help your reader find the information they need quickly.

ğŸ“œ Emphasize White Space: White space isnâ€™t wasted space, it is in fact essential for readability. Like a well-designed advertisement, a resume with balanced white space draws attention to key points and prevents the page from feeling overwhelming. Research done in the graphic design field emphasizes that white space enhances readability and legibility, allowing key information to stand out and reducing cognitive load for the reader.

ğŸ“œ Tailor and Highlight: Place the most relevant achievements and skills at the top of each section. You only have seconds to make an impression, so make those seconds count.

Make no mistake, folks. That resume is supposed to be a marketing tool and not just some laundry list of duties. The design and layout needs to reflect that. Just as advertisers use clean layouts to convey a message quickly, your resumeâ€™s design should allow hiring managers to see your value at a glance.

Whatâ€™s one thing you could do today to make your resume more readable?

hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#JobSearchStrategy hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#ProfessionalBranding

ğŸ“œ Tailor and Highlight: Place the most relevant achievements and skills at the top of each section. You only have seconds to make an impression, so make those seconds count.

Make no mistake, folks. That resume is supposed to be a marketing tool and not just some laundry list of duties. The design and layout needs to reflect that. Just as advertisers use clean layouts to convey a message quickly, your resumeâ€™s design should allow hiring managers to see your value at a glance.

Whatâ€™s one thing you could do today to make your resume more readable?

post_html:
Get Your Resume Noticed

8 Key Scannable Points (and What Recruiters REALLY Want to See ) hashtag
hashtag#ResumeTips
hashtag#JobSearch

Crafting a resume that gets past the initial screening can feel like cracking a code! Here are the top 8 things recruiters typically scan for (forget page count!):

Location: Make it easy for them to see if you're a local candidate.
hashtag#LocationMatters

Summary/Profile: Briefly showcase your key experiences and what makes you stand out.
hashtag#SellYourself

Company Name (1-3 sentence summary): Quickly explain what the company did (e.g., "Developed educational software for children" or "Managed social media campaigns for a non-profit").
hashtag#CompanyContext

Title: Highlight the specific role you held (use the same wording as the job description if possible).
hashtag#MatchTheJob

Dates: Be transparent about your employment history, including month and year (short stints are okay!).
hashtag#BeHonest

Metrics: Quantify your achievements whenever possible (e.g., "Increased website traffic by 20%"). Numbers grab attention!
hashtag#ResultsOriented

Education: Include it if it's relevant to the job (essential for some roles like doctors or engineers).
hashtag#RelevantDegrees

Technical Skills (if applicable): List relevant skills, but showcase them further in your bullet points with specific examples.
hashtag#SkillsShowcase

What else are recruiters looking for?

While "soft skills" aren't the answer this time, here are some recruiter favorites:
Clear and concise writing (avoid typos!) ï¸
hashtag#ProofreadLikeAPro
Strong action verbs that showcase your achievements (e.g., "spearheaded," "managed," "increased")
hashtag#ActionVerbs
Tailored content that speaks directly to the job description
hashtag#TailorMade

P.S. Big Company Work Experience? Be Specific!

If you worked for a giant like Google, mention the specific division or function (e.g., "Google Search Ads team" or "Google Cloud Platform engineering"). This clarifies your unique experience within the vast company.
hashtag#SpecificExperience

By focusing on these key elements, you can craft a resume that gets noticed and lands you that interview!
hashtag#LandTheJob

Reach out to people at the companies you're interested in and have conversationsâ€”people hire people, not resumes or job boards.

Use tools to identify relevant keywords and align your experience with the role. Itâ€™s a small effort that can make a huge difference.

Great content isnâ€™t just about writingâ€”itâ€™s about writing well. Yet, many writers (even experienced ones) fall into these common traps:
âŒ 1. Fluffy Introductions
ğŸ‘‰ Mistake: Taking too long to get to the point.
âœ… Fix: Hook your reader in the first sentence! Start with a bold statement, a stat, or a question.
âŒ 2. Overusing Jargon
ğŸ‘‰ Mistake: Using complex terms that confuse readers.
âœ… Fix: Write like you're explaining to a 10-year-old. Keep it clear and concise.
âŒ 3. Writing Without Structure
ğŸ‘‰ Mistake: Huge blocks of text that scare readers away.
âœ… Fix: Use headings, bullet points, and short paragraphs to improve readability.
âŒ 4. Forgetting SEO
ğŸ‘‰ Mistake: Writing great content but ignoring keywords.

âŒ 5. Weak Call to Action (CTA)
ğŸ‘‰ Mistake: Leaving readers without a next step.
âœ… Fix: End with a clear CTAâ€”whether itâ€™s subscribing, sharing, or commenting.

ğŸš€ Want to stand out in the competitive job market? Here are the top 3 things you can do to make your resume shine! âœ¨

1. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight the skills and experiences most relevant to the role you're applying for. A personalized resume shows employers that you're genuinely interested in the position and have the qualifications they're looking for.

2. Showcase Achievements: Instead of just listing your job duties, focus on your accomplishments. Use specific metrics and examples to demonstrate the impact you made in your previous roles. For example, "Increased sales by 20% in six months" or "Led a team of 10 to successfully launch a new product."

3. Highlight Soft Skills: Employers value soft skills such as communication, teamwork, and problem-solving. Make sure to include examples of how you've utilized these skills in your work experiences. Soft skills can set you apart from other candidates with similar technical abilities.

ğŸ’¼ Remember, your resume is your first impression â€“ make it count!

5 Tips for Acing Your Research Papers

Hi Associates,

Writing a research can be overwhelming but Here are 5 simple tips to write awesome papers:

 1. Know Your Goal: Understand the main point of your paper, what you want to use the research for and focus on that

2. Use Trustworthy Sources Only. Stick to reliable info like academic journals and government data. This will help make your data credible.
3. Stay Organized: Outline your ideas to keep things on track. Try not to use every information you find so that you don't end up being confused or deviating from the subject at hand.

 4. Properly cite the sources you use for your research to avoid plagiarism

5. Revise and edit multiple times for a polished paper. This helps to discover and correct mistakes.


Need a research writer? I am available to help you write amazing papers. DM me for a collaboration.

post_html:
Your IT/tech job descriptions might be turning candidates away. ğŸ›‘

This is how to fix them! âœ…

â¡ï¸ 1. Start with a clear job title
Avoid jargon or creative titles that confuse candidates. A straightforward job title like "Software Engineer" performs better in search results and aligns with candidate expectations.

â¡ï¸ 2. Include a strong opening summary
Summarize the role in 2-3 sentences. Focus on the core purpose of the job and how it contributes to the companyâ€™s goals, keeping it concise and engaging.

â¡ï¸ 3. Outline key responsibilities clearly
List the main tasks in bullet points. Be specific to avoid ambiguityâ€”avoid general phrases like "handle IT projects" and specify the exact responsibilities.

â¡ï¸ 4. Focus on day-to-day activities
Paint a picture of a typical day in the role. This helps candidates visualize the job and assess if it's the right fit for them.

â¡ï¸ 5. Specify required skills and technologies
Clearly list must-have technical skills, such as Python, SQL, or AWS. This filters candidates early and saves time for both parties.

â¡ï¸ 6. Differentiate between â€˜requiredâ€™ and â€˜preferredâ€™ skills
Clearly label "must-have" versus "nice-to-have" skills. This helps attract qualified applicants while keeping the door open for those who may have potential.

â¡ï¸ 7. Set realistic expectations for experience levels
Be precise about the experience level requiredâ€”whether it's entry-level or senior. Avoid broad terms like "junior" or "experienced" without clear year-based guidelines.

â¡ï¸ 8. Explain the purpose of the role
Describe why the role exists and how it fits into the company's broader goals. This provides context and meaning, motivating the right candidates to apply.

â¡ï¸ 9. Highlight career growth opportunities
Mention internal development programs or career paths. Candidates want to know how they can progress within your company, especially in a fast-paced industry like IT.

â¡ï¸ 10. Provide a clear reporting structure
State who the candidate will report to. This helps candidates understand where the role fits in the organizational hierarchy and clarifies team dynamics.

... and 14 further must-read tips in the carousel below!

post_html:
Did you recently get passed over for a role you thought you were a perfect fit for? Job hunting can be a challenging journey, and rejection, while tough, is often part of the process. Instead of letting frustration take over, take a step back and assess your approach. Are there areas where you could refine your strategy? Below are a few insights that might help you turn things around and boost your chances for success.

1. Are You Aiming Too High?
One common mistake candidates make is applying for roles that may be slightly out of reach. Itâ€™s natural to want to push for the next level in your career, but are your qualifications truly aligned with the position youâ€™re applying for?

If you find yourself consistently passed over for roles that require more experience or a broader skill set, it might be time to reassess and realign. Consider seeking a company with a clear advancement policy or a position that will help bridge the gap between where you are now and where you want to go. Remember: career growth is a marathon, not a sprint.

2. Have You Updated and Tailored Your Resume?
Your resume is the first impression you make on potential employers. Have you taken the time to thoroughly update it before submitting your applications? A rushed, generic resume could be the reason youâ€™re not getting callbacks.

Think carefully about the content youâ€™re showcasing. Are you just listing broad job duties, or are you clearly communicating your achievements and the value you've added in your previous roles? Employers want to see specific examples of how youâ€™ve contributed to the success of your past organizations. Instead of simply stating â€œresponsible for managing a team,â€ try adding more depth: â€œLed a team of 8 to successfully implement a project that resulted in a 15% increase in operational efficiency.â€

Refine each bullet point, focusing on accomplishments and measurable outcomes that highlight your unique value.

3. Are You Preparing for Interviews?
Winging it simply wonâ€™t cut it. The competition is fierce, and preparation is key. If youâ€™re not taking the time to prepare for interviews, youâ€™re missing out on one of your best chances to shine.

Think about your most significant career achievementsâ€”those moments that truly made an impact at your previous companies. Be ready to share specific metrics, numbers, and examples that demonstrate your value.

Itâ€™s also important to keep your answers concise. Hiring managers often have limited time, so make sure youâ€™re answering questions thoroughly without going off on tangents. Practice telling your stories in a clear, impactful way that highlights your expertise while remaining focused on the relevant details.

4. Bonus: Explore Interview Tips from Experts
If youâ€™re feeling stuck or unsure about how to best prepare for interviews, consider checking out resources like Janet Jonesâ€™ profile for a series of valuable tips on acing interviews.

post_html:
Here are my top tips to make your resume stand out!! The goal is clarity and readability. A well-organised, professional resume creates a positive first impression and helps employers quickly see why you're a strong candidate.

Over the next few weeks, I'll also provide tips on what to avoid including in your resume and seek your input on some debatable topics you might believe should be included.

START WITH THE BASICS - Create a clear, professional header with your name, in a larger font, (your header is the first thing employers will notice) and include in a smaller font your phone number and email for easy readability.

SUMMARY - Include a brief summary under your header highlighting your skills, experience, and career goals to showcase and make a strong first impression that youâ€™re the right fit for the job.

SKILLS - Highlight relevant expertise here, tailoring them to the job description and including transferable skills.

HIGHLIGHT YOUR ACHIEVEMENTS AND EDUCATION- List your degrees, certifications, courses, languages, awards, key achievements, professional memberships, accreditations, and volunteer work.

SOFTWARE â€“ List all software programs youâ€™ve used in a separate section under your achievements.

CAREER SUMMARY TABLE â€“ Provide a VERY BRIEF snapshot of your past roles under your listed software, including job title, company, and dates worked. Start with your most recent roles, and include your expanded detailed tasks separately on the following pages.

EMPLOYMENT HISTORY
â¦¿ Include company name, job title, promotions, exact dates, and if a permanent or a contract role.
â¦¿ Keep your resume concise - 1-3 pages max, or up to 4 if you have over 20 years of experience. List the last 15 years of experience in reverse order, condensing older roles past 15 years unless they are relevant to the job.
â¦¿ Dot point tasks - Write in first person without "I," e.g., â€œScheduled and organised client appointments.â€
â¦¿ Make it precise and measurable - saying â€œincreased sales by 20%â€ is more impactful than â€œimproved salesâ€, instead of â€œupdating clients,â€ say â€œupdated 60 clients weekly.â€
â¦¿ Include specific skills and highlight keywords from the job description in your resume to showcase your relevant experience.
â¦¿ Briefly explain employment gaps, whether due to travel, study, COVID, redundancy, family, or other reasons.

FORMATTING - Use a consistent 10-12 pt font, bold headers only, bullet points for tasks, and a professional font like Times New Roman or Arial. If using lines, keep them thin and light-coloured.

PROOFREAD â€“ Print or read your resume aloud to spot errors, and have a detail-oriented friend review it.

FINISHING TOUCHES - Name it properly, using your name followed by "Resumeâ€ and save your resume as a PDF to maintain its format.

"MOST IMPORTANTLY", BE HONEST - Honesty is key to your resume. Dishonesty can harm your chances and reputation. Stay truthful!

In todayâ€™s competitive job market, your resume is often your first impression with potential employersâ€”and it needs to shine. But what if writing isnâ€™t your strength? Thatâ€™s where hiring a professional resume writer can be a game-changer. However, not all resume writers are created equal, and investing in the wrong one could leave you frustrated or, worse, still unemployed.

Before you commit, here are three essential questions to ask to ensure youâ€™re making the right choice:

1. What is their experience and expertise?
Not every resume writer understands your specific field or career goals. Ask about their professional background and how long theyâ€™ve been writing resumes. Look for someone who understands your industry and has a proven track record of success. Bonus points if theyâ€™ve worked in recruiting or HRâ€”theyâ€™ll have insider knowledge of what hiring managers are looking for.

2. How do they tailor resumes to individual clients?
Avoid writers who rely on generic templates or canned phrases. A great resume writer will ask in-depth questions about your experience, achievements, and career goals. Their goal should be to tell your unique story while ensuring your resume passes applicant tracking systems (ATS). Be wary of anyone who promises a one-size-fits-all approach.

3. Can they provide examples, reviews, or testimonials?
Reputable resume writers will gladly share client testimonials or samples of their work. Seeing evidence of their ability to produce results can give you peace of mind. If theyâ€™re unwilling to provide this, it might be a red flag.
________________________________

A resume is an investment in your career, and choosing the right professional can make all the difference. Asking these questions ensures that youâ€™re selecting someone who understands your needs and can deliver real value.

Want even more tips on hiring the best resume writer? Check out our full blog for a deeper dive into these questions: [https://lnkd.in/gay-4HxU]

Navigate your career transition with your resume

Planning to change careers soon? Then, you need a strong resume to help you find a great opportunity, fast. Here are some of our best tips to navigate a career transition:

1. Identify transferable skills
Transferable skills help you emphasize knowledge areas that apply across industries and roles on your hashtag#resume.

2. Address employment gaps
It is normal to have one or two short gaps on your hashtag#resume. List your career gaps upfront and provide brief explanations for them.

3. Reframe your experience
Even if your past roles arenâ€™t related to the new job, you can present them on your hashtag#resume in such a way that they are relevant to the new scope.

4. Add new skills
Have you upskilled yourself for your career transition? Then, your new hashtag#resume must showcase your new skills and qualifications.

5. Highlight certifications
If you are transitioning into a field that requires you to be certified to practice, such as accounting, healthcare, or beauty, you should add your new certifications to your hashtag#resume.

Would Apple sell an iPhone in a plain cardboard box?
Would Nike slap a logo on a plain sneaker and hope for the best?

ğŸš¨ Are you looking for work? Applying to jobs and not hearing back?

Here are my Top 3 Tips for Job Seekers:
1. Crisp Resume
Write the value add that you bring to the table, your experience and expertise.
If you are a fresher, list out all the projects that you have done during your internship.

2. Alignment
Make sure that there is at least 70% overlap between your skills and what the hiring manager is looking for.

3. Certification is Good; Portfolio is Better
Nothing impresses more than the actual work (samples).
Your Portfolio, GitHub repo, Capstone projects, etc go a long way.


In the last 2 decades;
Conducted hundreds of interviews along with the hiring team;
I have appeared in 50+ interviews as a candidate;
Converted 20+ successfully.

Sharing what has worked for me over the years!
All the very best.


Hiring Managers,
If you are interviewing more than 20 candidates for a role, then STOP.
There is no perfect match, stop looking for one.

post_html:
âœ¨ğŸ“„ Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds ğŸ“„âœ¨
Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips:
1. Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. A reverse chronological order is often effective, listing your most recent activities first.
2. Keep It Concise: Aim for a one-page resume with consistent formatting. Use bullet points and simple sentences for clarity.
3. Be Honest: Always be truthful. Employers verify information, and honesty is key.
4. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention.
5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences.
6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests.
7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful.
8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors.
9. Use Keywords: Incorporate industry-specific keywords and phrases to make your resume relevant to recruiters. For example, if you're an Accounting major, include 'CPA Eligible by May 2025'.
10. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile.
Remember, a well-crafted resume can make a significant difference in your job application process. Let's make your resume shine! ğŸŒŸ

hashtag#ResumeBuilding hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#LinkedIn

post_html:
Here are some common resume pitfalls transitioning military job seekers fall into:

ğŸš© 1. The â€˜One-Size-Fits-Allâ€™ Resume

Using the same generic resume for every job application is a surefire way to get ignored.

Solution: Tailor your resume to each job by aligning your skills and experience with the job description.

ğŸš© 2. No Metrics, No Proof

Saying you "improved processes" in the military is vague. Saying you "increased efficiency by 30% and reduced costs by $50K" is impactful.

Solution: Use quantifiable achievements to show your value.

ğŸš© 3. The Job Description Copy-Paste Trap

Regurgitating your job duties from a military or corporate role isn't compelling.

Solution: Translate responsibilities into accomplishments. Hiring managers want to know how you made an impact, not just what you were assigned to do. Make sure to use action verbs, metrics, and show results.

ğŸš© 4. Too Much Military/Career Jargon

Don't use military jargon and acronyms that civilians don't understand.
If your resume reads like a mission report, it wonâ€™t resonate with civilian recruiters.

Solution: Simplify terminology and explain how your skills transfer to the industry youâ€™re targeting.

ğŸš© 5. Keyword Deficiency

Many resumes get rejected by recruiters because you are not proving how you meet the skills nor address the key words listed in the job description.

Solution: Don't just list all of your previous job responsibilities, use relevant industry keywords and skills from the job description, and SHOW how you've done THAT thing they want you to know how to do.

A resume isnâ€™t just a piece of paper; itâ€™s your personal marketing document.

Avoid these mistakes, and youâ€™ll get closer to landing an interview.

Maloney out! âœŒ

Here are some common resume pitfalls transitioning military job seekers fall into:

ğŸš© 1. The â€˜One-Size-Fits-Allâ€™ Resume

Using the same generic resume for every job application is a surefire way to get ignored.

Solution: Tailor your resume to each job by aligning your skills and experience with the job description.

ğŸš© 2. No Metrics, No Proof

Saying you "improved processes" in the military is vague. Saying you "increased efficiency by 30% and reduced costs by $50K" is impactful.

Solution: Use quantifiable achievements to show your value.

ğŸš© 3. The Job Description Copy-Paste Trap

Regurgitating your job duties from a military or corporate role isn't compelling.

Solution: Translate responsibilities into accomplishments. Hiring managers want to know how you made an impact, not just what you were assigned to do. Make sure to use action verbs, metrics, and show results.

ğŸš© 4. Too Much Military/Career Jargon

Don't use military jargon and acronyms that civilians don't understand.
If your resume reads like a mission report, it wonâ€™t resonate with civilian recruiters.

Solution: Simplify terminology and explain how your skills transfer to the industry youâ€™re targeting.

ğŸš© 5. Keyword Deficiency

Many resumes get rejected by recruiters because you are not proving how you meet the skills nor address the key words listed in the job description.

Solution: Don't just list all of your previous job responsibilities, use relevant industry keywords and skills from the job description, and SHOW how you've done THAT thing they want you to know how to do.

A resume isnâ€™t just a piece of paper; itâ€™s your personal marketing document.

Avoid these mistakes, and youâ€™ll get closer to landing an interview.

Maloney out! âœŒ

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!

Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:
âœ… Use standard headings:
 - Stick to common headings like â€œWork Experience,â€ â€œEducation,â€ & "Skills.â€

âœ… Keep formatting simple:
 - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.

âœ… Incorporate keywords:
 - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements.
- Try to match 70-80% of job description language

âœ… Use a professional & readable font:
 -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.

âœ… Tailor each resume:
 - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.

âœ… Quantify relevant experiences:
 - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.

Critical resume mistakes to avoid:

âŒ Omit personal details:
 - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.

âŒ Avoid complex designs:
 - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.

âŒ Exclude irrelevant experiences:
 - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.

âŒ Keep graduate resumes short:
 - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.
Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.

âœ… Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact.
âœ… Use relevant keywords from the job description.
âœ… Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables).
âœ… Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all wonâ€™t work.
âœ… Want better results? Apply online AND network with hiring managers!

Finally,
ğŸ‘‰ An ATS-friendly resume doesnâ€™t just pass the ATS, it gets you noticed by recruiters!
ğŸ‘‰ ATS is just a tool, it doesnâ€™t make hiring decisions!
ğŸ‘‰ ATS is not your enemy, it is a tool that helps recruiters.
ğŸ‘‰ Stop fearing it and focus on what you can control
ğŸ‘‰ Make your resume work for you!

Boost your job search with these strategies

Are you looking for your dream job in a congested job market? Then, you need to rethink your job-searching strategies.

1. Define your goals
Instead of blindly groping in the dark, start your job search with a clear goal and aim. First, decide what you want out of the job search.

2. Update your material
Now, you should update your resume, cover letter, and LinkedIn profile to suit your job search. Add the right keywords and info.

3. Network for success
Use your professional network to learn about new opportunities. You can get referrals and recommendations from your network.

4. Apply to job strategically
Choose jobs that match your skills and qualifications. Donâ€™t forget to choose jobs that you will enjoy doing.

5. Prepare for interview
The resume is not the only thing that needs to be polished. Brush up on your interviewing skills to ace your next job interview.

10 DeepSeek Prompts to Write A Killer Resume ğŸ‘‡

Turn your resume into a powerful tool that stands out!

[Save now or lose it forever] ğŸ”–

Use 10 Powerful DeepSeek prompts:

1ï¸âƒ£ Crafting a Standout Resume Summary/Headline

"How do I write a compelling resume headline or summary for a [job title, e.g., Project Manager] role that highlights my unique value in 1-2 sentences?"

2ï¸âƒ£ Quantifying Achievements in Work Experience

"Help me transform generic job duties into quantifiable achievements. For example, how do I showcase sales results or efficiency improvements using numbers?"

3ï¸âƒ£ Tailoring Skills for ATS Optimization

"What are the best ways to align my resumeâ€™s skills section with keywords from a job description to pass ATS filters? Provide industry-specific examples."

Writing a First-Class Resume Summary in 5 Steps

Your resume summary is the first thing recruiters readâ€”make it count! Hereâ€™s how to craft a killer summary that shows off your best skills and experiences:

1. List Your Best Qualities
Soft skills like communication or leadership shine here. Pick a few that align with the job description to spotlight in your summary.

2. Highlight Your Top Skills
Jot down your strongest technical skills and choose the ones that will catch the recruiterâ€™s eye first.

3. Choose Key Experiences
Think back on your most impressive professional experiences. Even if youâ€™re early in your career, internships or projects count!

4. Consult the Job Description
Compare your skills and experiences to what the job posting is asking for. Tailor your summary to match their needs.

5. Write Concisely
Keep it to two or four sentences. Use active voice and action verbs to make it punchy and memorable.

Why is your resume not getting the attention it deserves in a pile of hundreds? Could it be that it's not telling your unique story effectively?

A resume is more than just a list of job titles and duties.

Itâ€™s a marketing document that should sell your personal brand.

Each line should be purposeful and demonstrate value.

So, what makes a resume stand out in a sea of competitors?

Consider including quantifiable achievements rather than vague responsibilities.

Numbers convey impact and help employers visualize your contributions.

Have you customized it to your target role?

A one-size-fits-all approach could dilute your message and lessen your chances.

Taking the time to tailor your skills and experiences to align with the job description can make all the difference.

Have you had a friend or mentor review it for clarity?

Fresh eyes can catch errors you might have missed and offer new perspectives.

How do you ensure your resume leaves a memorable impression?

The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths ğŸ”Š

Thereâ€™s a lot of resume â€œwisdomâ€ floating around the internetâ€”but not all of it is accurate. Letâ€™s bust six of the most common resume myths and set the record straight:

1. Your Resume Must Be One Page
Not true! If you have substantial experience, itâ€™s okay to go up to two pages. What matters is how relevant and concise your content is.

2. Gaps in Your Resume Are Dealbreakers
Life happens! As long as you address gaps confidently and show how you stayed active or grew during them, it wonâ€™t sink your chances.

3. You Always Need References
Nope! Employers typically ask for references after youâ€™ve made it through the initial stages. Keep them on hand but off your resume.

4. Your Resume Should Be "Unique"
A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isnâ€™t necessary unless youâ€™re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.

5. You Have to List Your Full Address
The days of snail mail are over! Just list your city and stateâ€”no need for your full address.

6. Dates and Employer Names Arenâ€™t Important
Think again! Hiring managers want to know where you worked and for how long. Dates and employer names give your experience credibility.

post_html:
When I started looking for a job, people said I should apply to a lot of them. But it didn't work out that way. I applied to many jobs and often got no response.

Why? Because when we rush, we sometimes miss important details about what the job needs. It's like trying to hit a target without looking.

Instead of applying to tons of jobs randomly, it's better to focus on a few. Take time to understand what the job is about and what the company wants. Then, change your resume to match that. Make it fit what the company is looking for.

It's not about sending out a bunch of resumesâ€”it's about sending the right ones. Quality is more important than quantity. If you match your resume with the job, you're more likely to get a call.

So, don't worry about applying everywhere. It's not a race. Take your time, understand the job, and then make your move. It's about being smart, not just being fast.

hashtag#JobSearchTips hashtag#InterviewTip hashtag#ResumeTips

8 Essential Skills to Highlight on Your Resume


Enhance your resume by highlighting these essential skills and utilizing tools like :
https://lnkd.in/ga_CyE_7


In todayâ€™s competitive job market, showcasing the right skills on your resume is crucial to stand out to employers. Here are eight essential skills you should highlight:

1. Communication
Clearly convey ideas through writing and speaking.

2. Problem-Solving
Identify issues and develop effective solutions.

3. Technical Proficiency
Master relevant software and tools in your field.

4. Teamwork
Collaborate effectively with colleagues.

5. Leadership
Lead projects and guide team members.

6. Adaptability
Adjust to changing environments and challenges.

7. Time Management
Prioritize tasks to meet deadlines efficiently.

8. Critical Thinking
Analyze situations to make informed decisions.






---
Resume Tips and Tricks

- Tailor Your Resume: Customize it for each job to highlight relevant skills.
- Use Action Verbs: Start bullet points with strong verbs like "led" or "developed."
- Quantify Achievements: Include numbers to showcase your impact.
- Keep It Concise: Limit to one or two pages with clear information.
- Proofread: Ensure your resume is error-free.
- Highlight Soft Skills: Emphasize teamwork and adaptability.
- Include a Summary: Provide a brief overview of your qualifications.
- Clean Layout: Use organized sections and consistent formatting.


Follow these tips to create a standout resume that attracts employers and advances your career.

Iâ€™ve been deep in resume reviews over the past few weeks, and a few things have stood out. So, in the spirit of kindness and humor, here are some unsolicited tips to (hopefully) help you stand out in the best way possible:

ğŸ¨ Go easy on the colors. A small splash of color? Cool. A rainbow? Distracting. Subtle and professional is the way to go.
ğŸ“œ Get to the good stuff quickly. I promise, most recruiters donâ€™t spend much time on those paragraphs or â€œhighlightâ€ sections at the top. Put your experience front and centerâ€”I want to see what youâ€™ve done without scrolling through a novel first.
âš ï¸ Meet the minimum requirements (and be honest). If the role requires X, Y, and Z, please have X, Y, and Z. And lying on preliminary questions? Just donâ€™t. Itâ€™s awkward for everyone.
ğŸ“Š Skip the charts, graphs, and graphics. They look fancy, but honestly, I usually scroll right past them. They donâ€™t always add the value you think they do.
âœ‚ï¸ Less is more. A focused, impactful resume beats one crammed with every single task youâ€™ve ever done. Prioritize metrics and achievementsâ€”theyâ€™re your best friends.
ğŸ“¸ No pictures, please. That space is better used for youâ€”your experience, skills, and what makes you a great candidate.
ğŸ’¡ I know the job market is tough right now, and it can be hard to know what works. I hope these tips are helpful as you polish up your resume. And know this: Iâ€™m rooting for you all!

CV/Resume Building: Your First Step to Career Success

Your CV is often the first impression you make with a potential employer. Yet, many job seekers find themselves struggling with screening tests and not getting the calls they hope for. Instead of spending big on CV-building services, I believe the real investment is in timeâ€”and leveraging accessible tools like Canva, Adobe, or even simple MS Word.
Here are a few key tips to help you boost your CVâ€™s chances of passing those screening hurdles:

1. Keep it Precise - Especially for freshers, itâ€™s tempting to include everything. But remember, less is more. Seek advice from professionals in your field or a consultant to streamline your content and keep it relevant.

 2. Leverage AI Tools - Donâ€™t miss out on the power of design! Use AI platforms to give your CV a polished, modern look. Plenty of templates are available, and a well-designed CV stands out.

3. Formatting Matters - Ensure your CV is easy to read. Poor formattingâ€”like mismatched fonts, inconsistent alignments, and heavy bordersâ€”can overwhelm the reader. Keep it clean and simple.

4. Spell Check, Always - A CV with spelling or grammatical errors sends the wrong message. Always double-check and, if possible, ask someone else to review it too.

5. Highlight Relevant Interests & Achievements - Tailor your CV to the role you're applying for. Sure, your singing talent is great, but if youâ€™re applying for a finance role, highlighting your interest in business, finance, or the stock market will capture the recruiterâ€™s attention.

|| Brownie Tip ||

Use an ATS-Friendly Format - Here's a tip most people don't knowâ€”make sure your CV is ATS-friendly (Applicant Tracking System). Many companies use ATS to filter CVs before they even reach a hiring manager. Stick to standard fonts, avoid images or complex formatting, and use keywords from the job description to increase your chances of passing the automated screening.

Remember, a well-crafted CV isnâ€™t just a list of qualificationsâ€”itâ€™s your story in a nutshell. Spend the time to make it shine, and youâ€™ll find yourself one step closer to that dream job.

Huge thanks to CA Arushi Jain for sharing her insights on the concept of "ATS/STAR format." I really appreciate the knowledge and perspective!

âœ¨ Use Your Words Wisely â€“ Especially on Your Resume! âœ¨
Have you ever been told to use your words wisely? This advice doesnâ€™t just apply to conversationsâ€”itâ€™s crucial when crafting your resume.
When I come across a resume packed with words, no matter how well-written, it often misses the mark. Why? It doesnâ€™t tell your story. A resume like that could belong to anyone.
To make your resume uniquely yours, focus on these key elements:
 ğŸ”¹ Scope: Describe your roleâ€”what was the scale of your responsibilities? What volume or team size did you manage?
 ğŸ”¹ Success: Highlight your achievements. What results did you deliver? What makes you stand out?
 ğŸ”¹ Recognition: Were you the â€œManager of the Yearâ€? The go-to person for a major initiative? Share it!
Quantify your accomplishments with numbers, symbols, KPIs, and specifics to show your impact. Once you master this, youâ€™ll never view resumes the same way again.
Letâ€™s compare two examples:
 1ï¸âƒ£ Strategic leader, hands-on with the team, developing client-centric initiatives to deliver an exceptional client experience.
 2ï¸âƒ£ Strategic leader, motivating teams to deliver exceptional service, resulting in a 14% sales increase YOY and growing appointment business from 8% to 17% of total sales.
The second example tells a story. Itâ€™s clear, measurable, and impactfulâ€”and it speaks volumes about the candidate's contributions.
ğŸ’¡ Remember: Your resume should showcase your unique journey, not just a generic job description.

There is one phrase you should NEVER say to someone who is unemployed due to a layoff or something outside of their control.

"Enjoy your time off!"

Ah yes....because losing your job is the all expenses paid vacation that NOBODY asked for.

Let's be real:

âŒ Bills don't take a vacation. Rent, groceries, and student loans didnâ€™t seem to get the memo that you're â€œoff work.â€

âŒ Job searching is a full-time job. Updating resumes, networking, and applying to 10-15 jobs a day isn't sipping margaritas on the beach.

âŒ Stress levels are high when you are unemployed and "relaxing" is tough when you are wondering how long your savings account will last.

Instead of telling someone to "enjoy" their time off, try saying this instead:

âœ… "How can I support you?"
âœ… "Who can I introduce you to in my network that can help?"
âœ… "If you need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out."

Being unemployed is anything but a vacation.

These jobseekers didn't ask for this time off.

They want to get back to work.

Let's continue to support these jobseekers instead of giving them a "silver lining" speech.

post_html:
DEAR JOB SEEKERS

THIS IS WHAT INCREASES YOUR CV SCORE ON THE APPLICANT TRACKING SYSTEM (ATS)

1) SKILLS:
You can either have skills in your career objective, job bullet points, separate section or you can have skills in all the above mentioned.

2) LINKEDIN URL:
Adding a hyperlink to your Linkedin Profile will help you share information about yourself that might be too much for your CV.

3) CONTACT NUMBER AND E-MAIL ADDRESS
Tip: Employers will use either of these two to communicate, make sure the email address spelling is correct and the numbers arenâ€™t swapped around.

4) FILE NAME:
Always use your First Name and Surname, using anything else might cause your CV to be discarded or marked off as suspicious.

5) FILE SIZE
The file must be under 2 mb. If your CV is bigger than 2 mb you need to remove attachments (copies of qualifications, cover page pictures, photos) or simply re-save it in a different format that will allow for file compression.

6) FILE TYPE:
The recommended file type to use is PDF (Not scanned), you must be able to highlight the text. Word can be used as well but PDF will cause the least problems.

7) DATE FORMATTING:
Include the month and year for both the start and the end date, the most recent experience being at the top going down.

Have a productive day job seekers, youâ€™re all winners for not giving up!

hashtag#ResumeWriting hashtag#CVWritingServices hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerAdvise hashtag#2025Goals hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#JobSeekers

Recruiters donâ€™t read resumesâ€”they scan them.

That means if yours doesnâ€™t grab attention in seconds, itâ€™s getting skipped.

So, what actually makes a recruiter stop and take a second look?

Hereâ€™s a breakdown of how they think:

1ï¸âƒ£ The 6-Second Rule
â†’ Recruiters arenâ€™t reading essays. They skim for key details.

2ï¸âƒ£ Your Top Half Matters Most
â†’ Name, title, contact info, LinkedIn and a compelling professional summary should be on the top.

3ï¸âƒ£ Strategic Keywords
â†’ Use industry-specific terms in your headline and summary. If they donâ€™t see relevant skills fast, youâ€™re out.

4ï¸âƒ£ Showcase Your Expertise
â†’ Your headline should highlight what you bring to the table, not just your job title.

5ï¸âƒ£ Clean, Readable Formatting
â†’ If your resume looks cluttered, it wonâ€™t get read. Stick to clear fonts, white space, and a structured layout.

Think of your resume as a first impression. If it doesnâ€™t catch attention in 6 seconds, itâ€™s time for a revamp.

One of the biggest mistakes professionals make when job hunting is trying to do everything at once when it comes to their resumeâ€”creating, curating, and tailoring all in one sitting.

The result? Frustration, burnout, and a resume that doesnâ€™t do justice to your accomplishments.

Hereâ€™s how to simplify the process and build resumes that workâ€”without wasting time or energy.

1ï¸âƒ£ Create Your Master Resume
Start with a "base resume"â€”a document that lists everything youâ€™ve done. Jobs, projects, achievements, responsibilitiesâ€”get it all down without worrying about formatting or structure. The goal? To create a comprehensive record of your career history.

2ï¸âƒ£ Curate for Clarity
Now, trim it down. Organize your experience by grouping similar accomplishments and focusing on the most relevant wins. Think about the roles youâ€™re targetingâ€”what will make you stand out to recruiters or hiring managers?

This is where you shine! Use your curated content to craft tailored resumes that match specific job descriptions. Highlight the top 10% of your experience that aligns 100% with the job. Crafting an Impactful CV & Resume: Your Key to Career Success!

A well-structured CV (Curriculum Vitae) and Resume can make a significant difference in securing job opportunities. Whether you're applying for academic positions, research roles, or industry jobs, tailoring your document to highlight your skills, achievements, and experiences is essential.

ğŸ”¹ Key Differences Between a CV and a Resume:

âœ… CV: A detailed document (2+ pages) covering academic background, research, publications, and professional experiencesâ€”ideal for research, academia, and fellowships.

âœ… Resume: A concise (1-2 pages) summary of skills, work experience, and key accomplishmentsâ€”best suited for industry positions and corporate jobs.

ğŸ”¹ Essential Tips for Writing an Outstanding CV/Resume:

ğŸ“ Clarity & Structure: Use clear headings, bullet points, and a professional font for easy readability.

ğŸ¯ Tailor to the Job: Highlight relevant skills and experiences that align with the position.

ğŸ“Š Quantify Achievements: Use numbers and data to demonstrate impact (e.g., "Increased lab efficiency by 30% through optimized protocols.").

ğŸ’¡ Professional Summary: A strong opening statement should showcase your expertise and career goals.

ğŸš€ Use Action Words: Words like "Led," "Developed," "Implemented," and "Achieved" make your contributions stand out.

âœ… Proofread & Format: Eliminate typos, maintain a clean, professional layout, and ensure consistency in formatting.

A well-crafted CV/Resume not only opens doors but also tells your unique career story. Take the time to refine yours and make a lasting impression!
